importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Aryeh Zalmanovich, an 85-year-old Israeli captive, died in captivity in Gaza on this date, marking a significant moment in the ongoing body exchange under the ceasefire agreement.

Army Master Sergeant Tamir Adar was killed in fighting in southern Israel on this date, and his body was taken back to Palestinian territory, highlighting the ongoing conflict's impact on military personnel.
Israeli forces seized the Rafah border crossing on this date, cutting off humanitarian access and severely restricting movement in Gaza, a major point of contention in the ceasefire.
The International Court of Justice (ICJ) ordered Israel to reopen the Rafah crossing on this date, underscoring international legal efforts to ensure humanitarian access to Gaza.
A temporary ceasefire began on this date, allowing the Rafah crossing to reopen briefly for medical evacuations, but it was short-lived due to new Israeli evacuation orders.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The broader conflict between Israel and Hamas, beginning in October 2023, has continued into 2025, affecting body exchanges, prisoner releases, and humanitarian access to Gaza.

keyTakeAways: Israel and Hamas have exchanged the remains of 15 Israeli captives, including two identified as Aryeh Zalmanovich and Tamir Adar, under a ceasefire agreement.
Hamas claims Israel is violating the ceasefire by refusing to reopen the Rafah border crossing with Egypt, a critical route for humanitarian aid and medical access.

The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and Palestinian medical authorities have identified the remains of Palestinians killed in detention, with some found still shackled and showing signs of abuse.
Palestinian officials, including Ubai Al-Aboudi of the Bisan Center, argue that Palestinian prisoners are effectively 'hostages' due to detention without due process or charges.
Approximately 20% of the Palestinian population has been arrested or detained by Israel over decades, with conditions in detention deteriorating since the October 2023 war.
The Rafah crossing has remained closed since May 2024, despite an ICJ order to reopen, severely limiting humanitarian access and the movement of civilians and medical personnel.
Turkey, as a signatory to the US-led ceasefire deal in Sharm el-Sheikh, supports the ceasefire but criticizes Israel’s failure to fulfill key humanitarian and prisoner exchange commitments.

The ceasefire agreement includes Israel releasing about 2,000 Palestinian detainees and committing to return the remains of 360 deceased Palestinians, though recovery is slowed by ongoing conflict and control of Gaza.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Under a Gaza ceasefire agreement, Israel and Hamas have exchanged the remains of 15 Israeli captives, including two identified as Aryeh Zalmanovich and Tamir Adar. Despite these exchanges, Hamas accuses Israel of violating the ceasefire by refusing to reopen the Rafah border crossing with Egypt, which has been closed since May 2024. The closure restricts humanitarian aid and medical access to Gaza, drawing criticism from the United Nations and the International Court of Justice, which ordered the crossing reopened. Palestinian officials, including Ubai Al-Aboudi of the Bisan Center, argue that Palestinian detainees are effectively 'hostages' due to lack of due process and physical abuse. The ICRC and Hamas organized the body handovers, while approximately 20% of the Palestinian population remains detained. Around 13 more sets of remains are expected to be returned, though recovery is hindered by ongoing conflict and Israeli control of Gaza. The ceasefire, originally supported by Turkey and the US under former President Donald Trump, remains under strain due to unfulfilled humanitarian obligations.
title: Israel, Hamas return more bodies of captives under Gaza ceasefire deal
